history.content:
Hello-

You can't take any technical courses toward the 45 units P/NP. All of your 45 units must be taken for a letter grade.  If you have completed all the requirements you need to graduate, are in your final semester, and have placed yourself on the spring degree list, then you may take a technical course as pass/no pass. If you have questions about this, please see your ESS adviser. 

If you're an EECS major, you're correct- you need a total of 45 engineering units to graduate (not including other requirements, such as humanities/social sciences, natural sciences, mathematics, etc.). 

Just to be clear, your 45 engineering units are composed of 20 lower-division units (EE 20, EE 40, CS 61 series), 20 upper-division EECS units, and then 5 additional engineering units. The 5 additional engineering units must be technical engineering courses (graded) but do not have to be upper-division.  The 5 additional engineering units would not include DeCal courses or any of the self-paced CS 9 courses.  Many students just take 7 upper-division EECS but some students take E 120 (3 units) or IEOR courses (not 172, 190 series, 191).

Right now i have 3 techies, and i am considering making one of them Pass/Fail. 

Is that allowed? 


ALSO, to graduate, we just need 45 units in EE and CS, which means 5 upper div techies?
history.subject: Can you make upper divs pass fail and still adhere to all the policies of EECS department>?
